div.head: Title
div.p: Ruskin wrote the title “a theme” centered and on a line by itself above the text, just as he wrote the title “A sermon” centered and on a line by itself above the brief text that immediately precedes “a theme” on the same page of MS II. In both cases, it appears that Ruskin positioned the title prior to the text as if he was naming a routine genre or exercise.

div.head: Genre
div.p: If by theme Ruskin means a written exercise.

Ruskin calls this piece “a theme”, rather than a “sermon”, possibly because he did not hear the text in church. The discourse reads like notes on an address to a missionary society. Ruskin’s handwriting is unusually illegible for this piece.

div.head: Date
div.p: So dated by its position between A Sermon" ["beautiful allegory"] and On Skiddaw and Derwent Water" in MS II .

div.head: Discussion
div.p: While Ruskin's transcript contains too little detail to identify the specific occasion, the stir in the Ruskins' environment of worship in 1828 explains the kind of meeting he attended. On 14-16 May 1828, as documented at length by the Evangelical Magazine, to which the Ruskins subscribed, the London Missionary Society held its thirty-fourth annual meeting, commencing with a sermon preached by the Reverend Richard Alliott on the "Nature and Obligation of Christian Liberality". Based on Matthew 10, verse 8, "Freely ye have received, freely give", the argument explicated the Christian obligation of liberality as descending from the Apostles' endowment with "miraculous powers by the use of which they might bave enriched themselves" were it not that such use of their powers "was wholly inconsistent the chaaracter of . . . [Christ's] dispensation". Just so, Christians possess "the Gospel in our hands, conveying greater and better blessings;--for these we are indebted to the bounty of God, and it is according to his purpose that, that which we bave freely received, we should also freely communicate". If this sermon, or an address like it, was the occasion for Ruskin's theme, he might have picked up on the perorartion, which appealed to "Philanthropists, as above all other means calculated to ameliorate and improve the condition of the most barbarous and wretched of the human race; and to Englishmen, as involving in its results the honour and prosperity of our own country,--the cause of Missions being considered as, indeed, the cause of our countr--of the world--of the salvation of men,--and of the glory of our great Creator" ("Surrey Chapel", 261-62).

that recorded by Ruskin was the thirty-first anniversary of the Surrey Mission Society, which was celebrated on 9 April 1828 at "Dr. Andrews's Chapel, Walworth"--that is the Beresford Street Chapel, Walworth, built for the popular preacher by his parishioners.
